author: Mark Belko / Pittsburgh Post-Gazette
title: Sprint sign must go, city says after ruling
text:
Sprint sign must go, city says after ruling February 22, 2017 12:29 PM Sprint sign on Mount Washington that read: Pittsburgh WINS with Black & Gold, By Mark Belko / Pittsburgh Post-Gazette 
The city is demanding that Lamar Advertising immediately remove a vinyl Sprint advertising banner affixed to the former Bayer Co. sign atop Mount Washington after the Pittsburgh zoning board of adjustment found that it violated the law. 
In a decision dated Feb. 16, the zoning board denied a protest appeal filed by Lamar after the city law department ordered the gold banner with black lettering proclaiming, "Pittsburgh WINS with Black & Yellow" removed last June. 
The board found that the installation of the 7,200-square-foot vinyl static advertising sign as a replacement for a nonconforming 4,500-square-foot electronic sign violated a section of the city zoning code which states that nonconforming signs "may not be enlarged, added to or replaced by another nonconforming sign or by a nonconforming use or structure." 
In response to the decision, Katie O'Malley, spokeswoman for Mayor Bill Peduto, said, "The ZBA ruled in favor of the city on the Sprint sign. The city is requesting that Lamar remove this illegal sign immediately." 
“Lamar and Sprint have wasted taxpayer dollars by forcing us to defend the integrity of our city's scenic hillsides in court, and they have been in clear and blatant violation of our zoning and building code laws,” Mr. Peduto added. 
“It's beyond time for Lamar and Sprint to step up and do the right thing, remove this illegal sign, and come back to the table to propose a permanent reuse of the historic Mount Washington sign. They must remove what has become an embarrassing eyesore." 
Jonathan Kamin, attorney for Lamar, said the company was reviewing the decision and evaluating its options. "We haven't seen or heard anything from the city," he said, 
The Sprint banner, affixed to one of the city's most prominent and historic advertising spaces on the face of Mount Washington, created a stir when it was first erected. 
The law department sent cease-and-desist letters ordering the removal of the sign. The Department of Permits, Licenses and Inspections also issued a notice of violation stating the sign was put up without a permit. 
At the time, Mr. Kamin said that the use was permitted and in compliance with the applicable codes, an argument the zoning board rejected. 
According to the board's decision, the sign structure has been in place since at least 1933 and has been exclusively used for electronic messaging since then. Bayer ended its use of the sign in 2014. 
"The board unequivocally rejects Lamar's unsupported and unsupportable contentions that the installation of the 7,200 square foot vinyl sign on the sign structure was no different than changing the advertising copy on any of its other 900 billboards in the city and that Lamar had 'explicit rights’ to install the vinyl sign," its decision stated.
